user_message:
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. They will investigate the code fragments you give. Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule. Provide your answer with these fields. - suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code. It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags - explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated. It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated. DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments. Here is the code of init_response_body_data: ```c static int init_response_body_data (void) { if (0 != body_dyn_size) { body_dyn = (char *) malloc (body_dyn_size); if (NULL == body_dyn) { fprintf (stderr, "Failed to allocate memory.\n"); return 0; } if (tool_params.medium) { /* Fill the body with HTML-like content */ size_t pos; size_t filler_pos; static const char body_header[] = "\n" "\nSample page title\n\n" "\n"; static const char body_filler[] = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
\n"; static const char body_footer[] = "\n" "\n"; pos = 0; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_header, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header)); pos += MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header); for (filler_pos = 0; filler_pos < (body_dyn_size - (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header) + MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer))); ++filler_pos) { body_dyn[pos + filler_pos] = body_filler[filler_pos % MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_filler)]; } pos += filler_pos; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_footer, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer)); } else { /* Fill the body with binary-like content */ size_t pos; for (pos = 0; pos < body_dyn_size; ++pos) { body_dyn[pos] = (char) (unsigned char) (255U - pos % 256U); } } } return ! 0; } ``` Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I identified all conditional blocks and loops whose bodies may be statically or dynamically unreachable and therefore warrant investigation for MISRA Rule 2.1: the outer check on body_dyn_size (the whole allocation/population block), the malloc NULL-check (which causes an early return and makes the remainder of that path not executed on allocation failure), the medium/else branches (either branch could be impossible if tool_params.medium is effectively a compile-time constant or otherwise invariant), and the two loops that may never execute (the filler_pos loop and the binary-content pos loop) if their loop conditions evaluate to zero iterations for all possible inputs. These fragments are included so other reviewers can determine whether any of them are truly unreachable in the project.

Other parts of the function need not be investigated for unreachable-code concerns because they are ordinary statements or declarations that are executed conditionally depending on runtime values (e.g., memcpy calls, variable initializations, string declarations). There are no obvious always-false (e.g., if (0)) or always-true (e.g., if (1)) constant conditions, no code placed after an unconditional return within the same block, and no unreachable labels or dead-case switch sections present in this function. The reachability of the listed fragments depends on runtime values or external definitions (body_dyn_size, tool_params.medium, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_), so they are the relevant places to inspect further for MISRA Rule 2.1 compliance.
